abstract.para: A brief introduction to DocBook and the DocBook xslTNG Stylesheets.

chapter.title: What is DocBook?
chapter.para: DocBook is a very widely used XML vocabulary maintained by the DocBook Technical Committee of OASIS. It is particularly well suited to books and papers about computer hardware and software (though it is by no means limited to these applications).
DocBook started as an SGML DTD more than 30 years ago. It is now an XML vocabulary defined normatively by a RELAX NG grammar and Schematron rules.

chapter.title: Styling DocBook
chapter.para: The DocBook xslTNG Stylesheets are the thirdfifth generation of stylesheets that I’ve worked on for transforming DocBook into HTML and print. Before them there were:

listitem.para: The DocBook XSLT 1.0 Stylesheets, circa 2000 (still maintained).
The gmat formatter (successor to fmat), circa 1994.

(It was a bailing wire, duct tape, and chewing gum hack that I co-wrote for O’Reilly. It used objects in some early beta of Perl 5 to build a parse tree of the SGML ESIS from DocBook (1.x? 2.x?) sources. It generated troff markup from a recursive descent parse of the object tree. The less said, the better.)

chapter.title: What is DocBook xslTNG?
chapter.para: The DocBook xslTNG Stylesheets are XSLT 3.0 stylesheets for transforming DocBook to HTML. The goals are:

listitem.para: That looks good “out of the box” (on the web or in print)
Attempts to provide good accessibility features
And uses modern web features to provide an aesthetically pleasing presentation.

chapter.para: The design is generally cleaner and a focus on clean, semantic markup makes it easier to style and process in a formatter.
The standard distribution also includes extension functions to perform XInclude processing, syntax highlighting of verbatim environments, and extract metadata from images.

chapter.title: Multi-stage transformation
chapter.para: Multi-stage transformation makes the processing simpler:

listitem.para: Transform to HTML (for online or paged media)

chapter.para: The last stage is always looking at very consistent markup.

listitem.para: Since this isn’t a DocBook or xslTNG tutorial, let’s just look at some more interesting examples.

chapter.title: Callouts
chapter.para: A couple of functions from a Python program.

area.alt: This is not the first line of the script
Closed-form calculation of n’th Fibonacci number
Stackoverflow answer to the question “how do I make an ordinal number in Python”?

callout.para: This is an XIncluded fragment of the actual, executable program.
This is the closed-form solution to finding the “nth” Fibonacci number:

annotation.para: If you use , the stylesheets automatically include the libraries (or the MathML rendering libraries of your choosing). This allows you to display complex equations, of course, but it can also improve the appearance of even simple expressions, such as √5.
(This is an annotation, more about them in the next chapter.)

callout.para: The closed-form solution amuses me because I used calculating Fibonacci numbers (recursively) as an argument for greater expressive power in XSLT 1.0. “What if I wanted to number a list with the Fibonacci numbers?”
Stackoverflow showed me how to print the number as an ordinal.

chapter.para: Annotations, as the name implies, allow you to associate annotations with content in your document. Annotations are non-local (they’re associated by ID/IDREF not containment) and the linking markup is bi-directional. The same annotation can be used more than once.

Annotations can be rendered with or without JavaScript support. With JavaScript, the annotations are popups. Without JavaScript, they’re presented at the bottom of the page, similar to footnotes, but styled somewhat differently. In paged media, annotations are rendered as footnotes and their titles are ignored.

annotation.para: This one is pointless, but it is used twice.

annotation.title: Annotation, noun
annotation.para: According to Merriam-Webster, an annotation is a note added by way of comment or explanation. They give as an example quotation:

blockquote.para: The bibliography was provided with helpful annotations.

annotation.para: Annotations can point to the elements the annotate. Alternatively, elements can point to their annotations.

chapter.title: Extended Links
chapter.para: extended links, like annotations, can be non-local. The more interesting feature is that unlike HTML anchors, they can also have multiple endpoints. Consider the following link:
chapter.programlisting: <phrase xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:type="extended"> <link xlink:title="DocBook.org" xlink:label="target" xlink:href="http://docbook.org/" xlink:type="locator"/> <link xlink:title="DocBook on Wikipedia" xlink:label="target" xlink:href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DocBook" xlink:type="locator"/> <citetitle xlink:label="source" xlink:type="resource" >DocBook</citetitle> <link xlink:to="target" xlink:from="source" xlink:type="arc"/> </phrase>
chapter.para:
With JavaScript enabled, this link to
DocBook
has a popup menu to select the link target. Rendered without JavaScript, the link choices are presented as alternatives after the link. In print media, the link URIs are also shown in parenthesis.

annotation.title: Simplifying link markup
annotation.para: It’s worth noting that although the XLink vocabulary is defined purely in terms of attributes so that it can more easily be embedded in other vocabularies, there’s no reason a DocBook customization couldn’t use simplified markup to identify links:

In this example, I’ve adopted the convention that an extended-link element identifies an extended link with the semantic that target element(s) identify the link target and any other element identifies the source.
This is equivalent to the attribute form and could easily be translated into it.

chapter.title: On-page navigation
chapter.para: The on-page navigation feature helps the reader keep their place in long pages.
(This feature only applies to online presentations.)

chapter.title: Paged media
chapter.para: All of these features also work in paged media as well.

chapter.title: Online
chapter.para: All of these features also work online as well.

bibliography.title: References
bibliography.bibliomixed: CSSCSS Specifications. World Wide Web Consortium. 2020.

XIncludeXML Inclusions (XInclude) Version 1.0 (Second Edition). World Wide Web Consortium. 2006.

colophon.title: Colophon
colophon.para: This book was authored in DocBook 5.2 with Emacs. It was formatted for presentation with the DocBook xslTNG Stylesheets version using . It was formatted as PDF by Antenna House.
